name: Manasseh
description: Firstborn son of Joseph, named 'causing to forget' because God made Joseph forget his hardship. Received Jacob's left-hand blessing though he was firstborn. 'He also shall be great' â€” blessed but second. The pattern of biblical reversals: firstborn displaced, yet still honored.

receiving-left-hand.name: Receiving the Left Hand
receiving-left-hand.description: Jacob's left hand on Manasseh's head - the lesser blessing
receiving-left-hand.expression: accepting with dignity, blessed though second
receiving-left-hand.prompt: young boy kneeling or standing before elderly Jacob - the patriarch's left hand placed on his head, right hand crossed over to Ephraim. Face perhaps showing slight confusion or dignified acceptance. The firstborn receiving the lesser portion. 'He also shall be great.'
receiving-left-hand.energy: blessed though second, dignity in displacement

with-grandfather.name: Before Grandfather Jacob
with-grandfather.description: Manasseh presented to Jacob for blessing
with-grandfather.prompt: young boy approaching elderly patriarch Jacob - firstborn bearing, expecting to be first. Egyptian-Hebrew clothing, positioned at Jacob's right (expecting the right-hand blessing). Joseph nearby, about to see his father's surprising choice.

crossed-hands-moment.name: The Crossing of Hands
crossed-hands-moment.description: Manasseh's perspective on Jacob's deliberate crossing
crossed-hands-moment.prompt: view from Manasseh's position - Jacob's arms visibly crossed, left hand on his head though he stands at the right. Perhaps confusion on young face as expectations are overturned. Ephraim beside him receiving the right hand. The moment of displacement.

father-protests.name: Joseph's Protest
father-protests.description: The moment Joseph tries to correct Jacob's hands
father-protests.prompt: Manasseh watching as Joseph reaches to move Jacob's hands - 'Not so, my father, for this one is the firstborn.' Natural order being defended, but Jacob refuses to change. The boy watching his father fight for his precedence, but providence overrules.

he-also-great.name: He Also Shall Be Great
he-also-great.description: Manasseh receiving his own blessing and promise
he-also-great.prompt: young Manasseh receiving Jacob's promise - 'He also shall become a people, and he also shall be great.' Face showing acceptance, perhaps comfort. Second but not forgotten. The firstborn who became second but was still blessed.

standing-with-ephraim.name: Standing with Brother
standing-with-ephraim.description: Manasseh and Ephraim together, both blessed
standing-with-ephraim.prompt: two young brothers standing together after blessing - Manasseh beside Ephraim with dignity intact. Both blessed, both loved, both becoming tribes. United despite the distinction in their blessings. 'God make you like Ephraim and Manasseh.'

forgetting-hardship.name: Causing to Forget
forgetting-hardship.prompt: young man or symbolic representation - his name means 'God made me forget all my hardship and all my father's house.' Perhaps showing transition from Egyptian imagery to new identity. Healing from Joseph's trauma, new family beginning.

rivalry-receiving-blessing.name: Rivalry: Receiving the Left Hand
rivalry-receiving-blessing.prompt: Young Manasseh receiving Jacob's left hand on his head, perhaps looking confused at the crossing. He stood at the right, expecting the right-hand blessing. The firstborn receiving the lesser portion, but blessed nonetheless. 'He also shall be great.'

rivalry-both-blessed.name: Rivalry: Both Blessed
rivalry-both-blessed.description: Manasseh beside Ephraim, both receiving blessing
rivalry-both-blessed.prompt: Manasseh beside Ephraim, both touched by Jacob's hands. Both blessed, both loved, both part of Israel. Not rejected but different. The dignified firstborn standing with the chosen younger, united despite the distinction.
rivalry-both-blessed.energy: Unity in difference, both blessed, no bitterness
